Due to the complexity and variety of functions required for a comprehensive situational awareness system during natural disasters, it is difficult to provide a complete example code here. However, here is an example code snippet for integrating an open-source GIS tool with a guidance system for a drone:
```python
import geopandas as gpd
from shapely.geometry import Polygon

# Load the disaster data into a GeoDataFrame
disaster_data = gpd.read_file('path/to/disaster_data.shp')

# Define a polygon representing the search area for the drone
search_area = Polygon([(lon1, lat1), (lon2, lat2), (lon3, lat3), (lon4, lat4)])

# Select the disaster events that intersect with the search area
disaster_events = disaster_data[disaster_data.intersects(search_area)]

# Create a list of waypoints for the drone to follow
waypoints = [(lon1, lat1, alt1), (lon2, lat2, alt2), (lon3, lat3, alt3), (lon4, lat4, alt4)]

# Initialize the drone guidance system
guidance_system = DroneGuidanceSystem()

# Set the drone's mission to follow the predetermined waypoints
guidance_system.set_mission(waypoints)

# Fly the drone over the disaster events and stream live video to the ground station
for event in disaster_events:
    guidance_system.fly_to(event.geometry.centroid.x, event.geometry.centroid.y, event.geometry.centroid.z)
    guidance_system.start_video_stream()

# Return the drone to its starting point and land
guidance_system.return_to_home()
guidance_system.land()
```
This code demonstrates how a GIS tool can be used to select disaster events within a search area, and how the drone guidance system can be used to fly over those events and stream live video to the ground station. Of course, this is just a small part of a larger situational awareness system, but it gives an idea of how these different technologies can be integrated.
